statement.text: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aorta, typically at the isthmus (just distal to left subclavian artery origin, near the ligamentum arteriosum). It represents 5-8% of congenital heart disease and is associated with bicuspid aortic valve (50-75%), intracranial aneurysms, and other cardiac defects. Classic presentation is upper extremity hypertension with weak/delayed femoral pulses.
statement.formal: Coarctation: Discrete aortic narrowing at isthmus (juxtaductal); Associations: BAV (50-75%), intracranial aneurysm, VSD, Turner syndrome; Presentation: upper extremity HTN, radial-femoral delay

explanation.intuition: Coarctation is like a kink in the main garden hose coming from your house. The pressure builds up before the kink (upper body = high blood pressure) but is low after it (lower body = weak pulses). The body tries to compensate by growing extra blood vessels (collaterals) around the blockage, but the heart still works harder than it should pumping against the obstruction.
explanation.key_insight: Coarctation is not just an aortic problem - it's part of a generalized arteriopathy. Even after successful repair, patients remain at risk for hypertension, aortic aneurysm, and premature cardiovascular disease. Lifelong surveillance is required.
explanation.technical_details: Location is typically at the isthmus - the junction of aortic arch and descending aorta, where the ductus arteriosus inserted. Two theories: (1) ductal tissue extending into aortic wall constricts as ductus closes, (2) reduced fetal aortic flow from associated intracardiac defects leads to isthmus underdevelopment. Collaterals develop via internal mammary, intercostal, and scapular arteries (rib notching on CXR).

by_location.juxtaductal: Most common - at level of ligamentum arteriosum
by_location.preductal: Proximal to ductus - severe, presents neonatally, ductus-dependent
by_location.postductal: Distal to ductus - may present later in life

by_presentation.neonatal: Severe obstruction, ductus-dependent, presents with shock when PDA closes
by_presentation.childhood_adult: Collaterals developed, presents with hypertension, heart failure, or incidentally

physical_exam.blood_pressure: Upper extremity > lower extremity by â‰¥20 mmHg
physical_exam.pulse: Radial-femoral delay; weak or absent femoral pulses
physical_exam.auscultation: Systolic murmur over back (collaterals), continuous murmur

chest_xray: '3 sign' (indentation at coarctation with pre/post dilation)

neonatal.medical: Prostaglandin E1 to keep ductus open

older.balloon_angioplasty: Native coarctation - increasingly first-line in discrete lesions
older.stenting: Preferred in adults with native or recurrent coarctation
older.surgery: Extended resection and end-to-end anastomosis; subclavian flap; interposition graft

definition.@value: Congenital discrete narrowing of the aorta at the isthmus causing upper body hypertension and associated with bicuspid aortic valve

clinical_pearls: Upper extremity HTN + weak femoral pulses = coarctation until proven otherwise
50-75% have bicuspid aortic valve - always check
Lifelong surveillance needed even after 'successful' repair
